story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in Mali, there was a young boy named Biram. Biram was a kind and curious boy who loved to explore the world around him. He would often wander through the Savannah, marveling at the towering baobab trees and the countless stars that filled the night sky.

One day, while Biram was out on one of his adventures, he came across a small, injured bird. The bird had a broken wing and was unable to fly. Biram knew he had to help the bird, so he gently picked it up and carried it back to his village.

He took the bird to the village healer, a wise old woman named Fanta. Fanta examined the bird and told Biram that she could mend its wing, but it would take some time. Biram was overjoyed and promised to take care of the bird until it could fly again.

He named the bird Kélé and cared for it with great love and devotion. Every day, he would feed it and talk to it, and every night, he would sing it lullabies to help it sleep.

As the days passed, Kélé's wing began to heal, and Biram knew it was time for the bird to return to the wild. He took Kélé to the top of the tallest baobab tree and gently lifted its wings.

Kélé looked at Biram, then at the endless sky before it, and took off into the air. Biram watched in awe as Kélé soared higher and higher, until it was just a small dot in the distance.

From that day on, Biram knew that he had the power to make a difference in the world, no matter how small. And every night, as he lay in bed, he would look up at the stars and think of Kélé, and the adventure that awaited him in the morning.

And so, Biram went to bed with a heart full of joy and hope, knowing that tomorrow would bring new wonders and new friends. And with that thought, he drifted off to sleep, ready for another day of adventure.

The end.

Note: This story is a fictional one, but it is inspired by the rich culture and beautiful landscapes of Mali, and the values of kindness and compassion. I hope you and your son enjoy it.
